channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Dozens Are Killed in Blast at Factory in Eastern China
item.description: At least 65 people were killed Saturday morning when a blast tore through a metal products factory in China’s eastern Jiangsu Province, state-run news media reported.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: World Briefing: China: Blast at Work Site Kills Dozens
item.description: An explosion killed between 40 and 65 people at a workshop in an eastern Chinese city, China state media reported.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: The Netherlands: A Greenpeace Ship Heads Home After a Russian Ordeal
item.description: The Greenpeace ship departed for the Netherlands nearly a year after Russian authorities seized it during a protest against an oil platform, Greenpeace International said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: North Korea’s Antipathy for the U.S. Is Seen at a New High
item.description: North Korea’s deputy permanent representative, Ri Tong-il, recited grievances with the United States and South Korea, accusing them of conspiring for regime change in the North.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Quick History: This Time, a Different Kind of War Between Israel and Hamas
item.description: With the collapse of a 72-hour cease-fire, it is difficult to see how the bloodshed can be stopped.
item.dc:creator: By SERGE SCHMEMANN
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry faces an increasingly uphill battle in his cease-fire negotiations.

item.title: World Briefing: Japan: Names Given to Disputed Islands
item.description: Japan on Friday gave names to five uninhabited islets in an island group at the center of a territorial dispute with China as part of efforts to reinforce its claim, drawing quick condemnation from Beijing.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Birthright Trips to Israel Continue Despite Mideast Conflict
item.description: There have been some cancellations since the hostilities began, but 6,000 young people have visited Israel as planned.
item.dc:creator: By ELENA SCHNEIDER
item.media:description: Lila Faria, 19, at her home in Maplewood, N.J. Ms. Faria, a student at New York University, recently returned from a trip to the Middle East with the Taglit-Birthright Israel organization.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: A Creole Solution for Haiti’s Woes
item.description: Children should learn in the language they speak at home, not French.
item.dc:creator: By MICHEL DeGRAFF and MOLLY RUGGLES

item.title: Anti-Semitism Rises in Europe Amid Israel-Gaza Conflict
item.description: Attacks, threats and hate speech have yielded alarm among many Jews and stern language from government leaders.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: Protesters in support of Palestinians in Gaza last weekend displayed a swastika at a Paris rally. The demonstration had been banned by the government and prompted deployment of police.

item.title: Britain Fails to Find Riches It Expected in Swiss Accounts
item.description: When the British tax authorities struck a landmark deal with the Swiss to crack down on tax evasion, they sat back and waited for the cash to flow in. Almost three years later, they are still waiting.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE and DOREEN CARVAJAL
item.media:credit: Niels Ackermann for The New York Times
item.media:description: The banking industry in Zurich is centered on a square called Paradeplatz, where companies like Credit Suisse are based.

item.title: Gaza Fighting Intensifies as Cease-Fire Falls Apart
item.description: A cease-fire in Gaza collapsed on Friday as the Israeli military said that two soldiers had been killed and a third apparently captured. Gaza health officials said at least 70 Palestinians had been killed by Israeli airstrikes.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Israeli officials said Second Lt. Hadar Goldin was abducted; two other soldiers were killed.

item.title: A Test for Ukraine in a City Retaken From Rebels
item.description: In Slovyansk, a city of 80,000 that was a stronghold for pro-Russian rebels, Ukraine authorities have a difficult task ahead to shift the loyalties of residents to keep the peace.
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nadezda Ivanovna, 84, of Slovyansk, a city held by pro-Russian rebels who have since fled.

item.title: Investigators in Ukraine Begin Long-Delayed Search of Plane Crash Site
item.description: Dutch and Australian police officers on Friday were finally able to fan out over the Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 crash site and to search for human remains overlooked by local workers.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: International experts were at the site of the downed Malaysia Airlines plane in Ukraine on Friday.

item.title: In India, Kerry Seeks Compromise With Prime Minister
item.description: During his first meeting with the recently elected Nerendra Modi , the secretary of state tried to improve relations and close a divide over a trade treaty.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Obama Casts Doubt on Chances of Gaza Cease-Fire
item.description: President Obama on Friday demanded that Hamas release a captured Israeli soldier unconditionally and expressed pessimism that another cease-fire could be reached.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
item.media:description: President Obama spoke in the White House Briefing Room on Friday afternoon

item.title: In Tunnel War, Israeli Playbook Offers Few Ideas
item.description: Though Israel knew about Hamas’s tunnels, it has been surprised by how the militant group trained its fighters to use them.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers prepare to enter Gaza.

item.title: Insurgents Kill a Lawmaker in Somalia
item.description: Gunmen killed the lawmaker, Aden Madeer, as he left a mosque in Mogadishu. He was the fifth member of Somalia’s Parliament to be killed by insurgents this year.
item.dc:creator: By MOHAMMED IBRAHIM

item.title: 2 Palestinians Killed in West Bank Clashes
item.description: The two Palestinians were fatally shot by Israeli security forces during clashes in the West Bank, according to the Palestinian news media.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Break in Fighting Lets International Team Reach Site of Ukraine Crash
item.description: Ukrainian officials said they had suspended offensive operations against pro-Russia rebels to allow the monitors to reach the site safely.
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER and ANDREW ROTH
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier and vehicles from the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: French TV Executive Aims to Entertain North Africa, Too
item.description: Bouchra Rejani, an Arab immigrant, says she has never felt out of place in a country that has had a troubled history of integrating people from her background.
item.dc:creator: By AIDA ALAMI
item.media:credit: Lauren Fleishman for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I liked the idea of producing feel-good programs that were about surpassing yourself and transmitting knowledge, ” said Bouchra Rejani is one of the most successful television producers in France.

item.title: Kerry Calls on Qatar and Turkey to Gain Release of Israeli Soldier
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry asked the two nations to use their influence after the abduction, which took place shortly after a cease-fire was to go into effect.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Uganda Anti-Gay Law Struck Down by Court
item.description: A panel of five judges ruled on narrow technical grounds, preserving the possibility that the measure could be altered and revived.
item.dc:creator: By JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: Judge Stephen Kavuma read a verdict invalidating Uganda's anti-gay law in court on Friday.

item.title: John F. Tefft, a Career Diplomat, Will Go to Russia
item.description: John F. Tefft, a career diplomat, who was nominated without objections, will fill a post that had been vacant since February.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW SIDDONS

item.title: Ebola Virus Is Outpacing Efforts to Control It, World Health Body Warns
item.description: Leaders of the affected countries and the head of the World Health Organization introduced a $100 million plan to combat the disease that will allow hundreds of medical professionals to be deployed to West Africa.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Disinfectant is used in an attempt to prevent the spread of the Ebola virus at a government building in Monrovia, Liberia.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Anticorruption Campaign Targets Second CCTV Head
item.description: Liu Wen, the director of China Central Television’s documentary channel, CCTV-9, and producer of the hit series “A Bite of China,” has been detained on suspicion of corruption.
item.dc:creator: By MIA LI
